p: Applications written using Scala and Play Framework 2.1.0+

Browsers are capable of displaying HTML and executing JavaScript. If the application does not escape special characters in the input/output, and reflects user input as-is back to the browser, it is vulnerable to a Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attack. Through XSS, an attacker can steal or manipulate customer session and 
cookies and use it to impersonate the valid user, execute malicious 
files, install Trojans, redirect a user to a malicious site, and so on.
There are two types of XSS: non-persistent (or reflected) XSS, and persistent (or stored) XSS.
Non-Persistent XSS. A non-persistent attack requires a user to visit a link specially crafted by the attacker. When the user visits the link, the crafted code will get executed by the user’s browser.

Persistent XSS. In a persistent attack, the code injected by the attacker will be stored in a secondary storage device (usually on a database). A persistent attack is more harmful than a non-persistent attack.

By default, Play’s template engine prevents XSS vulnerabilities. Everything you write literally in a template is considered HTML by Play, and output is un-escaped. This HTML is always written by the template author, so it is considered safe. Other than the default HTML page contents, Play’s template engine automatically escapes strings by default. Still, as a best practice, always escape special characters before they are displayed to the user screens.

a) When you really need to insert un-escaped HTML in your templates, use the raw() method or the HTML() method on the string or use a verbatim tag in raw HTML. But if the string comes from a user input, sanitize it first.b) To set up a stricter escaping rule, edit the function escape in the Play framework source at location ~/framework/src/play/src/main/scala/play/api/templates/Templates.scala and then build the source again. Alternatively, if you are building from GitHub source, edit the file at location https://github.com/playframework/Play20/blob/master/framework/src/play/src/main/scala/play/api/templates/Templates.scala and add in additional filtering rules before you build the source.c) Set the HttpOnly flag in the cookie. This is an additional flag that is used to prevent an XSS exploit from gaining access to the session cookie. In XSS, an attacker commonly accesses the session cookie, and subsequently hijacks the victim’s session. Thus, the HttpOnly flag is a useful prevention mechanism. To enable the flag, enter the below command in the application.conf file:
By default this flag is set to false.  Note  If Cookie class is used, httpOnly is set to true by default and would be overridden only if explicitly set to false.
For defense-in-depth, always sanitize user input via the HtmlFormat.escape() method. It creates a safe(escaped) HTML fragment.

html:
Applies to

Applications written using Scala and Play Framework 2.1.0+

Vulnerability Description

Browsers are capable of displaying HTML and executing JavaScript. If the application does not escape special characters in the input/output, and reflects user input as-is back to the browser, it is vulnerable to a Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attack. Through XSS, an attacker can steal or manipulate customer session and cookies and use it to impersonate the valid user, execute malicious files, install Trojans, redirect a user to a malicious site, and so on.

There are two types of XSS: non-persistent (or reflected) XSS, and persistent (or stored) XSS.

Non-Persistent XSS. A non-persistent attack requires a user to visit a link specially crafted by the attacker. When the user visits the link, the crafted code will get executed by the user’s browser. 

Persistent XSS. In a persistent attack, the code injected by the attacker will be stored in a secondary storage device (usually on a database). A persistent attack is more harmful than a non-persistent attack. 

How to Fix

By default, Play’s template engine prevents XSS vulnerabilities. Everything you write literally in a template is considered HTML by Play, and output is un-escaped. This HTML is always written by the template author, so it is considered safe. Other than the default HTML page contents, Play’s template engine automatically escapes strings by default. Still, as a best practice, always escape special characters before they are displayed to the user screens.

a) When you really need to insert un-escaped HTML in your templates, use the raw() method or the HTML() method on the string or use a verbatim tag in raw HTML. But if the string comes from a user input, sanitize it first.
b) To set up a stricter escaping rule, edit the function escape in the Play framework source at location ~/framework/src/play/src/main/scala/play/api/templates/Templates.scala and then build the source again. 
Alternatively, if you are building from GitHub source, edit the file at location https://github.com/playframework/Play20/blob/master/framework/src/play/src/main/scala/play/api/templates/Templates.scala and add in additional filtering rules before you build the source.
c) Set the HttpOnly flag in the cookie. This is an additional flag that is used to prevent an XSS exploit from gaining access to the session cookie. In XSS, an attacker commonly accesses the session cookie, and subsequently hijacks the victim’s session. Thus, the HttpOnly flag is a useful prevention mechanism. To enable the flag, enter the below command in the application.conf file:

application.session.httpOnly=true

By default this flag is set to false.  Note  If Cookie class is used, httpOnly is set to true by default and would be overridden only if explicitly set to false.

For defense-in-depth, always sanitize user input via the HtmlFormat.escape() method. It creates a safe(escaped) HTML fragment.
